subject: Critical Thinking
title: The Narrative Fallacy: Stories Beat Statistics
description: A micro-lesson that makes The Narrative Fallacy: Stories Beat Statistics usable.

hook.text: One crying child on TV raises millions. A statistic of 100,000 deaths raises nothing. Stories beat numbers every time.

buildup.text: The narrative fallacy: we prefer stories to data because our brains are wired for narrative, not statistics.

discovery.text: Nassim Taleb: we construct stories after the fact to explain events that were actually random or multi-causal.

twist.text: Biographies of successful people create false narratives: 'She succeeded because of grit.' Ignoring luck, timing, &.

climax.text: Stories make sense of chaos. That's their power â€” and their danger. Sense-making isn't truth-finding.

punchline.text: A good story isn't good evidence. It's just memorable.

quiz.question: What is the narrative fallacy?
options: We prefer narratives over data and construct false causal stories
Statistics are more convincing than stories
